awd_titl_txt: Alternation of Generations without Gamete Fusion
awd_abstract_narration:
Reproduction by gamete fusion is the norm in the biological world; however, non-fusion reproduction occurs widely, including among land plants. If harnessed, non-fusion production of seeds will change the way hybrid seeds, such as corn, are currently made in agriculture. In order to understand the mechanisms of non-fusion reproduction, we propose to first understand how non-fusion embryos are formed in a simpler group of plants - ferns. Ferns are non-seed plants that lack the storage part of a seed but nonetheless form an embryo as the result of a sperm fertilizing an egg (fusion). The salient feature of a fern is having the sperm and egg producing parts of the plant housed in a tiny, free-living entity independent of the mother plants. Therefore this tiny, simple, green entity provides a rare opportunity to study the mechanisms of fusion reproduction, and important to this project, the non-fusion formation of an embryo without fertilization. Using this system, the genes key to non-fusion reproduction will be identified and their functions in this process tested. This research program will emphasize the identification and training of talented female scientists and data from the proposed research will be used in an undergraduate course.

Normally performing the essential roles of gamete formation and fertilization, the macroscopic gametophytes can also be coaxed to produce sporophytes without fertilization, a process called apogamy. In the reverse process, apospory, sporophytes can be made to produce gametophytes without meiosis. With apogamy and apospory, ferns can exhibit non-fusion alternation of the sporophyte and the gametophyte generations. This level of plasticity alternating between the two generations is not seen in seed plants. Thus, the apogamy and apospory of ferns offer an ideal system to answer the question that lies at the heart of non-fusion reproduction: Which genes control the developmental pathways leading to the gametophyte or the sporophyte generations? It is hypothesized that many genes that control fusion reproduction in ferns and seed plants are conserved and non-fusion reproduction in land plants has arisen by altering these genes. Furthermore, the non-fusion alternation of generations through apogamy and apospory in the model fern C. richardii occurs by altered regulation of a set of genes that normally are reserved for initiating embryogenesis from a zygote and gametogenesis from a spore, respectively. The research team has built up necessary technology and materials including apogamy induction, stable gene transfer, C. richardii transcriptome, and whole mount in situ methods. These will be used to achieve the goal of identifying key genes and gene networks involved in apogamy and apospory in the model fern C. richardii with the following specific aims: Studying the role of the candidate genes in fusion/non-fusion alternation of generations in C. richardii, gene discovery for apogamy and apospory in C. richardii, and functional analysis of newly discovered genes that are predicted to act in non-fusion alternation of generations in C. richardii.

Intellectual Merit

Regeneration in plant transformation remains a bottleneck for crop improvement in certain species or cultivars. Recently, morphogenetic transcription factors (MTFs) such as BBM and WUS have been found to increase regeneration efficiency. Around the same time (2017), we discovered that BBM and ANT promote apogamy in the model fern Ceratopteris. In apogamy, haploid gametophyte cells convert to the diploid sporophyte developmental pathway bypassing fertilization. Thus, these MTFs not only promote sporophyte regeneration from sporophyte in seed plants but also can alternate the gametophyte to the sporophyte generation asexually in the fern. Interestingly, we found that WUS did not promote apogamy. Due to the importance of the WOX gene family (of which WUS is a family member) in stem cell maintenance in seed plants, we investigated the five family members in Ceratopteris and discovered that CrWUL, the closest homolog to WUS is not expressed in the shoot meristem and instead functions in the vasculature. Our research extended to a lycophyte and provided critical support for the progenitor function of WUS being in the vasculature (Figure 1).

To investigate apospory, a process in which gametophytes are produced from young sporophyte leaves bypassing meiosis, the EMS1 gene was chosen as a candidate gene. EMS1 is a LRR receptor kinase that interacts with the peptide ligand TPD1 to restrict the number of reproductive cells in Arabidopsis anther. We isolated a CrEMS1 gene prior to the publication of the fern genome and discovered that this gene plays a major role in suppressing sporangium formation on vegetative leaves of the fern sporophyte (Figure 2) and promotes antheridium formation in the gametophyte. Suppressing the transition from vegetative growth to reproductive growth is a new function unknown to seed plants. Uncoupled sporogenesis and gametogenesis in the fern allowed us to dissect CrEMS1’s functions in the two generations, an advantage unmatched by the seed plants. We subsequently found three other CrEMS1 genes in the Ceratopteris genome; unveiling their functions will uncover the dynamic role of EMS1 in the evolution of reproductive development in vascular plants.

The identification of apogamy commitment genes in gametophytes is the aspect of the project still being completed. We are currently strengthening the bioinformatics analysis by mapping the reads to the recently published Ceratopteris genome.

In sum, we have identified genes promoting apogamy and genes potentially affecting apospory. Importantly, investigation into their normal functions in the fern provided critical insights in the evolution of stem cell maintenance and reproductive transition in vascular plants.

 

Broader Impact

Ferns are under-investigated vascular plants; our findings provide critical knowledge for future research in both seed and seed-free plants. In order to make these discoveries, we developed essential techniques including gametophyte transformation, creating RNAi lines, and improved whole mount gametophyte in situ hybridization that has propelled research in seed-free plants.

This research project trained 1 post-doctoral researcher, 3 PhD, 2 MS, and 11 undergraduate students. These include 64% female, 2 underrepresented minority, and 1 first generation college students. For outreach, we offered summer workshops for local high school students with hands on experience working with Ceratopteris.
